bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John R. Kissinger, March 21, 1941

div1.p: Hench informs Kissinger about his plans to purchase the site of Camp Lazear and the remains of Building No. 1. He discusses his correspondence with Kean and Truby and his intention to find incontrovertible evidence concerning the yellow fever story.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John R. Kissinger, March 21, 1941
div1.opener:
Camp
Lazear.
March 21, 1941
Mr. John R. Kissinger
Route 2 Box 1332
St. Petersburg, Florida
My dear Mr. Kissinger:
div1.p:
I was quite surprised to hear from you in Florida and am indeed
sorry that you are on the west coast whereas I will be on the east coast with my
wife and three children. I leave here today and will be at the Villa Atlantique
Hotel, Palm Beach for about three and a half weeks except that I will go alone to
Havana about March 28 for about one week. I want to conclude arrangements to
purchase the site of Camp Lazear and the remains of Building #1. I have had
much correspondence the past year about this and hope to be able to tell you all
about it sometime. Mr. Moran has helped me a lot and introduced me to the owners
of the land and so forth.

When I get this matter concluded, I will send you a copy of a
fairly long report on The True Location of Camp Lazear which I am submitting to
the Minister of National Defense in Cuba; the land may be memorialized by the
Government. It is possible that sometime this summer, I may stop over to spend
another day with you in Huntington. I also have had much correspondence with
General Truby - almost volumes, also with General Kean, and I am slowly getting
the details of the story ironed out. I intend to keep at it until the whole
truth is known. Incidentally it is Truby's recollection that you volunteered
first and I intend to straighten out the little tangle between you and Johnny
Moran by getting incontrovertible evidence. If I can, I hope to find evidence
that will be more important than memory which is often so faulty. I understand
that it may still be possible to uncover in Washington, the records of the Post
Hospital and that may have much data in it.

As for the Wyeth Company portrait, I am very glad that they have
accepted my suggestions about the proposed scene and I am delighted that they plan
to have you and Moran in it as representatives of all the soldier volunteers. I
know Mr. Kellogg will appreciate any help you can give him.

I know you will be most interested in my report to Doctor Ramos
whenever I can get a copy to you. It is illustrated with 50 photos, maps, and
records. I still plan definitely to write-up your story and publish it under your
name bit I want to straighten out some of the disputed points. Then no one can
doubt what you or I say.
Please give my best to Mrs. Kissinger.
div1.closer: Always sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:FP
